Question text: \text{Let }L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be a language with } LL = Σ^{*}. \text{ Which statements are true?}
Explanations: \text{ If L were finite, LL would also be finite}
\text{ Since }ε \in \Sigma^{∗}, ε \text{ must also be in LL}
\text{ It holds that }LLL = Σ^∗L ⊇ Σ^∗ \text{ because }ε ∈ L

Question text: \text{Let }L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be regular. Which of the following languages are regular? }
Explanations: \text{ This is }L^R L; \text{ regular Languages are closed under concatenation}
\text{ Counterexample:} L = \Sigma^* \text{ Then L is the Language of palindromes which isn't regular! }\
\text{ e.g Be L} = (ba*). \text{ Then the language is} \{ baⁿbaⁿ | n ∈ ℕ \}, \text{ which is not regular.}

Question text: \text{ Which of the following context-free grammars are ambiguous?}
AnswerOptions: S → TT; T → aT | bT | a | b
Explanations: \text{One counterexample: 'aaa' has two parse trees }
\text{ Terminals are generated right to left }
\text{One counterexample: 'aaa' has two parse trees }

Question text: \text{ Let }A ⊆ Σ^* \text{ be regular and } B⊆ Σ^* \text{ context-free. Which of the following languages are context-free?}
Explanations: \overline B \text{ might not be context free so (context free Languages not closed under complement) so the whole expression might not be context free}
\text{ A is regular and so also context-free; union of context-free languages is closed}
\text{ A is context-free; concatenation of contextfree Languages is closed}

Question text: \text{ Let } L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be a finite language with } |L| = |L^∗|.\text{ Which statements are true?}
Explanations: \text{Every finite Language is regular and L is finite.}
L^*\text{always contains }\epsilon \text{. So L also has contain at least one thing.If it is a Letter }x \in \Sigma, |L^*| \text{ is infinite, so it can only be that } L =\{ \epsilon \}
L = \{\epsilon\} \text{ implies that both absolute values are 1}

Question text: \text{ Let } L ⊆ Σ^∗\text{ and }L' := {w ∈ L : |w|² ≤ 10|w|}.\text{ Which statements are true?}
Explanations: \text{L´ is finite since }|w| \leq 10 \text{since all finite languages are regular, L` is too}
\text{since L´ is regular and every regular language is context free}
\text{since L´ is regular and every regular language is deterministic context free}

Question text: \text{Let } L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be regular and } k > 0.\text{ Which of the following languages are regular?}
Explanations: L ∩ (Σ^k)^* \text{ is regular;regular languages are closed under intersection}
= L^k; \text{ and regular languages are closed under concatenation}
\text{ For }k = 2, \text{ known to be non-regular (Language of Palindromes)}

Question text: \text{ Let }L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be context-free. Which of the following languages are context-free?}
Explanations: \text{ context free languages are not closed under complement}
L^R \text{ is context free so }L ∪ L^R \text{is the Union of two context free languages, which is closed under Union}
\text{ context free languages are not closed under intersection }

Question text: \text{ Let G be the grammar with productions } S → aT, T → Sb. \text{ Which statements are true? }
Explanations: \text{Production: T → Sb is not right-linear}
\text{G does only have Variables on the left side of productions.}
L(G) = ∅, \text{ so regular}
L(G) = ∅, \text{ so contextfree}

Question text: \text{We consider the language }L :=\{ aⁿbᵐcᵐ | n,m ∈ ℕ\} \text{ over } \{a,b,c\}.
AnswerOptions: \text{ There exists a DPDA accepting L by final state }
\text{ There exists an NFA recognizing L}
\text{ There exists a DPDA accepting L by empty stack}
Explanations: L \text{ is deterministic context free(only m to match) so there is A DPDA}
L \text{ isn't regular.}
\text{Prefix Condition:If a valid string is prefix of another valid string,no DPDA can recogniz it. Here: a,aa}

Question text: \text{Let }A, B \text{ be languages over the same alphabet.}
AnswerOptions: \text{ If  A and B are not regular, then } A ∪ B \text{ is not regular}
\text{ If A is regular and B is context-free, then } A ∩ B \text{ is context-free}
\text{If }A ∪ B = B ¸\text{ and }B \text{ is regular, then } A \text{ is regular}
Explanations: \text{Counterexample:}
\text{Sadly you just need to know this.}
A ∪ B = B \text{ just says }A \subseteq B \text{ a subset of a regular language doesnt have to be regular,e.g choose }B= \Sigma^* \text{and A any contextfree language}

Question text: \text{Define }L_1 := \{uv | u,v \in \Sigma^*, u ≠ v\}, L_2 := \{uv | u,v \in \Sigma^*,|u| = |v|\}.
Explanations: L_1 \text{ is actually just the Language beginning with one Letter (u) of }\Sigma \text{ and then  optionally adding more (u) -> regular }
L_2 \text{is just the Language of words with even length. Concatenating it x times doesnt change that.}
L_1,L_2\text{ are regular, since regular Languages are closed under union, this is true.}

Question text: \text{We consider the language }L := \{v₁bw₁\#v₂aw₂ | v₁ = v₂ ∧ w₁ = w₂\}.
Explanations: \text{L contains no word starting either with }ab\#bb\text{ nor with }a\#b \text{so the residual languages is }\emptyset
\text{L contains no word starting either with }aba\#ba\text{ nor with }ab\#ba
\text{L contains no word starting either with }ab\#\text{ nor with }ba\#

Question text: \text{Let }A, B ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be languages. Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: \{uv : u ∈ A, v ∈ B\}^2 = \{uv : u, v ∈ AB\}
Explanations: \text{ Counterexample: }A = \{a, aa\}
\text{ Both equal to }(AB)^2
(A ∪ B^*)^2 \text{ all just add to A,The expression is always at least as big as A}

Question text: \text{Let }M = (Q, Σ, δ, q₀, F) \text{be a DFA. A state } q ∈ Q \text{ is called a trap state if no final state is reachable from }q i.e. δ(q, w) ∉ F \text{ for all }w ∈ Σ^∗. \text{ For which of the following regular expressions r does there exist a DFA M with L(M) = L(r) and no trap state?}
Explanations: δ(q_0, ba) \text{ is always a trap state }
δ(q₀, a) \text{ is always a trap state}
\text{ From every state, reading ba leads to acceptance, also valid is that Answer 1 and 2 a obviously false and so this one is correct.}

Question text: \text{Let } M = (Q, Σ, Γ, q_0, Z_0, δ, F) \text{be a PDA with n states and k stack symbols.We convert M to a context free Grammar according to the lecture. What is the maximum number of non-terminal symbols that G can have? }
Explanations: V = Q × Q × Γ × ∪ {S}

Question text: \text{ Which of the following languages are context-free?}
Explanations: S → AS B | ε, A → aa | ab, B → ab | bb
\text{ Same argument as for } \{a^n b^n c^n: n ∈ ℕ\}
S → aaS | ε; \text{ the language is even regular.}

Question text: \text{For an NFA or DFA } M = (Q, Σ, δ, q_0, F) \text{ and state } q ∈ Q, \text{ we write } L_M(q) \text{ for the words that M accepts starting in state q. Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: \text{ There is a connected NFA M with state q and }L(M) = \{aa, ba\}^* \text{ and }LM(q) = \{ab\}^*.
\text{There exists a connected NFA M with state q and }L(M) = \{aa, ba\}^*\text{ and }LM(q) = \{aa\}^*.
\text{ There is a connected DFA M with state q and }L(M) = \{aa, ba\}^* \text{ and }LM(q) = \{a\}\{aa, ba\}*.
\text{There exists a connected DFA M with state q and } L(M) = \{aa,ba\}^* \text{ and } L_{M}(q) = \{a\}^*
Explanations: \text{ Then M would accept a word that ends with b.}
\text{ Since} \{aa\}^* ⊆ L(M), \text{ one can always add such a state to an NFA for }L(M).
\{a\}\{aa, ba\}^* \text{ is a residual language, the statement holds for all }M.
\{a\}^∗ \text{is no residual Language of M.}

Question text: \text{Let }A, B, C ⊆ Σ^* \text{ be languages. Which of the following statements are true? }
Explanations: \text{ Counterexample:} A = \{a, b\}, B = \{a, b, ab \}
\text{Holds for all Sets -> since Languages are just set for those as well.}
\text{ Counterexample: } A = B = \{a, aa\}

Question text: \text{Let r be a regular expression and M an NFA with n states and }L(M) = L(r). \text{ Which statements are true? }
AnswerOptions: \text{ There is an NFA for }L(ar) \text{ with at most n+1 states.}
\text{There is an NFA for }L(rar) \text{ with at most n+1 states.}
\text{ There is an NFA for }L(ra) \text{ with at most n+1 states.}
Explanations: \text{We add a new initial state with an a-transition to the old initial state.}
\text{ Counterexample: r = a. There is an NFA M with 2 states, but for L(aaa), every NFA has at least 4 states.}
\text{ We add a new final state f. The old final states are no longer final and receive an a-transition to f. }

Question text: \text{Let G be a context-free grammar with 7 productions. Which statements are true?}
Explanations: \text{Counterexample: }S -> ABCD....
